title: What UK Supreme Court ruling means for Brexit
text:
“The most significant and historic constitutional court ruling that we’ve had in all of our lifetimes.”

That was the verdict of Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon on today's Supreme Court's ruling that Boris Johnson's decision to suspend the U.K. parliament was "unlawful" and therefore had, in effect, never actually happened.

Reading out the judgment, Brenda Hale, the court's most senior judge, painted a colorful image. "When the Royal Commissioners walked into the House of Lords [with the order to prorogue parliament] it was as if they walked in with a blank sheet of paper," she said. That meant the prorogation was "void and of no effect. Parliament has not been prorogued."

The unambiguous verdict from the U.K.'s highest court is a severe political blow to Johnson. He is accused of effectively lying to the queen and trampling on parliamentary sovereignty. In the short term, the most tangible impact is that MPs will be back at work on the green benches Wednesday. Speaker John Bercow announced shortly after the verdict that parliament would resume business at 11:30 a.m. — (almost) as if nothing had happened.

That means Brexit-skeptical MPs can harry the government with urgent questions to ministers and searching committee inquiries. They can keep demanding answers about the progress of the Brexit talks and the government's preparations for no deal with the power to force ministers to come to the despatch box. And all that scrutiny will be launched from what MPs regard as a lofty moral high ground.

But aside from increasing the political volume in Westminster, what impact will it have on Brexit? In the short term, not much. MPs already managed to rush through legislation which they believe prevents Johnson's government from pursuing a no-deal Brexit. So on the face of it, Johnson's best option is still to achieve a deal with the EU that can win enough parliamentary support to allow the U.K. to leave on October 31.

Perhaps most significantly, the court's judgment appears to close off one potential option for No. 10 Downing Street — a further prorogation to force through a no-deal Brexit. Given the unambiguous nature of the judgment (and the fact that it was unanimous) that is surely now off the table.

This insight is from POLITICO's Brexit Files newsletter, a daily afternoon digest of the best coverage and analysis of Britain’s decision to leave the EU available to Brexit Pro subscribers. Sign up here.
description: The judgment is a severe political blow to Boris Johnson but it doesn’t alter Brexit timeline.
